title: Café owner defends asking breastfeeding new mum to ‘cover up’
text:
The restaurant owner said she didn’t mean to upset the mum (Pictures: Getty/Google)

A café owner who told a breastfeeding mum to ‘cover up’ has defended herself after she was criticised for her actions.

Francesca Truss, who runs The Kitchen in Ilminster, Somerset, approached the new mum and told her she was ‘embarrassing’ an elderly customer on October 3.

The mum, who did not want to be named, had been breastfeeding her three-week old daughter and was left so ‘mortified’ by the incident she left the café soon after.

She then took to the cafe’s Facebook page the following day to complain about her experience.

Ms Truss claims she has since been the subject of ‘disgraceful’ social media comments, including people threatening to come and ‘squirt milk on her’ in protest.

The mum wrote on Facebook: ‘I was really shocked after the way I was treated when visiting this cafe yesterday.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I met a friend for coffee and was breastfeeding my three-week-old baby when I was asked to cover up so as not to embarrass the other customers.

The new mum complained on The Kitchen’s Facebook page and said she was ‘mortified’ (Picture: Google)

‘It was made out that the old gentleman in the corner was embarrassed.

‘But when he left and we questioned the owner this wasn’t the case at all, it was the owner that had the issue with me breastfeeding.

‘I was told that I need to remember it’s a “generational thing”. I’d like to add I was being as discreet as possible and even wear layers to enable me to do this.

‘I was the one that was left feeling extremely embarrassed and mortified. We promptly finished up and left.’

‘This is normally such a friendly welcoming place so I was extremely disappointed with this attitude, especially in this day and age,’ she added.

Ms Truss said young mums ‘need to realise there are other people around’ and is conscious she has a lot of elderly customers coming into her café.

She said: ‘I wouldn’t have gone out of my way to upset or hurt her, that wasn’t my intention.

Under the Equality Act a mother does not have to cover up if she doesn’t want to (Picture: Getty)

‘I was trying to look after all of my customers. Just because someone feels uncomfortable it doesn’t mean they are nasty.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Under the Equality Act 2010, a business ‘cannot discriminate against mothers who are breastfeeding a child of any age’ and a mum doesn’t have to cover up if she doesn’t wish to.

Ms Truss said she didn’t know it was ‘against the law’ and insisted she didn’t mean to upset the mum.

Since the incident, a number of people have taken to social media to condemn the cafe as ‘not child friendly’ and Ms Truss said she has received a ‘nasty’ backlash.

She said she would never ask someone to stop breastfeeding – but admits asking her to cover up to prevent an elderly customer feeling embarrassed, despite the man not saying anything about it.

Across Somerset, efforts are being made to make the county a welcoming place for breastfeeding, as it has been made a public health priority by Somerset County Council.

Organisers of Positive About Breastfeeding said people and businesses shouldn’t be shamed and their scheme is about tackling misinformation around the subject.

Emily Hutt, health promotion manager, said: ‘By supporting the increase in breastfeeding prevalence, we are going some way to reduce inequalities experienced by some groups within the population.

‘It is the right of the mother to choose how, and where to feed their baby. We would encourage everyone in Somerset to respect the choice of the mother/family and to be sensitive to the challenges they may be facing as a parent.

Advertisement

‘This may be with regards to infant feeding or anything that could present itself when transitioning into parenthood.’

description: The new mum left the café 'mortified' after being told to cover up while at The Kitchen, in Somerset.
